awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Chemical Ionization Mass Spectrometer for Measuring Organic Compounds at the Interfaces of Earth’s Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This MRI project supports the acquisition of a GC-Vocus-2R instrument that will enable research scientists to obtain significant detail about the composition of organic compounds in the atmosphere. The instrument is a next-generation tool that will better constrain the fate and impacts of organic carbon emitted to the atmosphere and enable a better understanding of the interactions of organic carbon with ecosystems, organisms, and human activities.  The instrument is expected to provide the sensitivity, time resolution, specificity, and detail necessary to probe current outstanding questions in atmospheric and environmental chemistry across interfaces.

The GC-Vocus-2R uses proton transfer reaction mass spectrometry (PTR-MS) to measure organic gases, classified by molecular formula, with fast time response and can be transported and deployed for in-situ sampling. The PIs have identified the following topics to focus their research using the new instrument: Focus Area 1: Fundamental processes in atmospheric chemistry; Focus Area 2: Feedbacks and couplings between the biosphere and atmosphere; Focus Area 3: Impact of organic carbon on ecosystems and other environments. 

This instrument will support an interdisciplinary team of faculty at Virginia Tech who are investigating the role of gas-phase organic compounds in atmospheric chemistry, chemical signaling, insect ecology, freshwater ecosystems, and public health, with projects planned to tackle complex global issues that bridge these disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A large mass of organic compounds, containing primarily carbon, oxygen, and hydrogen, is constantly from human-driven and natural sources (e.g., vehicles, industry, vegetation). These compounds, and their reaction products, have critically important effects on human health, ecosystem function, and global climate. However, measuring these compounds and their transport between Earth’s systems is difficult due to the large variety of compounds and chemical reactions in the atmosphere and the dynamic nature of the complex mixture. This grant enabled the acquisition of a Gas Chromatograph “Vocus” Proton Transfer Reaction High Resolution Mass Spectrometer (GC-Vocus-2R), that enables new measurements of these compounds in the atmosphere across a wide range of systems.

Intellectual merit: The instrument acquired is one of the only existing tools that can provide the sensitivity, time resolution, specificity, and detail necessary to probe current outstanding questions in atmospheric and environmental chemistry across interfaces. By expanding the institutional capabilities of the university, and bringing together faculty across many disciplines (ecology, biology, atmospheric science, chemistry), this project has addressed a wide variety of questions. Projects enabled by this instrument have included: quantifying emissions from wildfires to better model and understand wildfire smoke, studying interactions between mosquitoes and their host species, measuring the efficacy of agricultural pest mitigation strategies by measuring emissions from pheromone bait traps, quantifying the removal of gases from the atmosphere during rain to improve big-picture modeling approaches, and studying interactions between surfaces and gases to understand transport of hazardous materials. Many of these projects will continue beyond the project period as they advance and are disseminated to the scientific community. This wide range of projects advances not only many of the research priorities in atmospheric chemistry identified by the National Academy of Sciences, but also several of the NSF’s 10 Big Ideas, and has built a multi-disciplinary community of researchers that will continue to benefit from this acquisition for the next decade.

Broader impacts: With use by researchers across the university, this instrument has broad scientific value to advance knowledge in a wide range of scientific and engineering fields that have direct societal impact. For example, research on emissions of wild vs. prescribed fires will provide data to decision makers and improve regulatory models, while studying emissions from pheromone traps will improve agricultural practices. Policy-relevant outcomes such as this are common across many of the projects enabled by this acquisition. This project has also contributed to the careers of many early-career researchers by advancing their research, providing training on state-of-the-art instrumentation, and establishing mentoring relationships. Several postdoctoral and graduate student researchers were advanced toward careers made directly possible through their experience operating state-of-the-art mass spectrometers, and this acquisition was used in hands-on learning in a graduate class. As the lifetime of this acquisition is expected to be a decade or more, the careers of many early-career researchers will be impacted by this project, and the scientific inquiry enabled will have broad-reaching effects.
